titleStmt.title: Antioxidant adaptive response in human blood mononuclear cells exposed to UVB

affiliation.orgName: Institute of Biochemistry and Biophysics. School of Pharmacy and Biochemistry
Institute of Biochemistry and Biophysics. School of Pharmacy and Biochemistry

analytic.title: Antioxidant adaptive response in human blood mononuclear cells exposed to UVB

biblStruct.note: Received 23 April 1996', accepted 2 August 1996

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: Human blood mononuclear cells exposed to UVB radiation develop increased antioxidant enzyme activities. Catalase (5.50 + 0.65 pmol (mg protein)-~), CuZn-supemxide dismutase (16.7 + 2.1 pmol (mg protein)-1), Mn-superoxide dismutase (11.3 +_ 1.7 pmol (rag protein)-'), Se-dependent glutathione peroxidase (13.2 + 1.5 mU (mg protein)-~) and Se-independent glutathione peroxidase (3.30 _ 0.52 mU (rag protein)-t) activities increase by 1.3-1.5-fold from the control activities after exposure to 0.3 W m-2 of 280-315 nm light for 15 rain and a 3 h dark incubation period. DT-diaphorase activity (2.86+0.21 itmol DCPlP rain-' (rag protein)-m) increases threefold from the in¢,~',ated control values. In contrast, cytochrome oxidase (0.36+0.04 mint (k') (rag protein)-~) and succinate dehydrogenase (3.06 4-0.25 ILmol DCPlP min-~ (rag protein)-m) activities remain unchanged during the same irradiation and incubation period. The treatment of cells with cycloheximide prevents the response triggered by UVB exposure. These findings suggest that an inducible antioxidant defence mechanism operates on photo-oxidative stress and that both superoxide dismutase and DT-diaphorase may display a concerted antioxidant role.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: The biological effects of UVB radiation (280-315 nm) in isolated cells appear to involve endogenous photosensitization and the primary formation of singlet oxygen and superoxide anion [1][2][3]. Human blood mononuclear cells develop an antioxidant response to photo-oxidation, such as an increase in the activities of CuZn-and Mn-superoxide dismutase, catalase and Se-and non-Se-containing glutathione peroxidases [4,5]. This antioxidant adaptive response appears to be directed towards the maintenance of low intracellular steady state concentrations of superoxide anion and hydrogen peroxide and a low rate of reactions initiated by oxygen free radicals [6][7][8].

Cells adapt to lethal changes in the environment by inducing the expression of protective stress genes [9]. This phenomenon was first observed with heat shock with the synthesis of heat shock proteins [ 10], allowing the cells to Abbreviations: DCPIP, 2,6-dichlorophenol-indophenol; RB, rose bengal; UVB, ultraviolet B, UVA, ultraviolet A; UVC, altravlolet C * Con~pond~ng a~*Y~r, Tel.: + 54 1 962-792,~; fa~: + 54 1 962-7928.

recover and to survive a repeated, more severe stress [ 11 ]. Because so many stimuli elicit the same cellular defence mechanism, researchers commonly refer to it as the stress response through the expression of stress proteins [ 12]. The adaptation of bacteria to oxidative challenges has been extensively studied [ 12]. Analogous responses have been identified in human cells, such as the induction of haem oxygenase by UVA/H202 [ 13], tyrosine phosphatase by H202, UV and menadione [ 14] in fibroblasts and superoxide dismutase by paraquat [ 15] in leukocytes. Lymphocytes show increased antioxidant enzyme activities when supplemented with rose bengal (RB), and a threshold of chromosomal damage (two chromosomal aberrations per cell) is apparently required to activate oxidative stress genes [4]. Human blood mononuclear cells exposed to visible light (400-550 rim) show increased activities of superoxide dismutase, catalase, glutathione peroxidase and DT-diaphorase, with a small decrease in cell viability [5].
The aim of this work was to describe the adaptive response of human blood mononuclear cells to UVB stress (280-315 nm) in terms of the synthesis of antioxidant and related enzymes.

div.head: Chemicals
div.p: Hystopaque 1077, Dulbecco phosphate-buffered saline (DPBS, D-5780), eyeloheximide and D-glucose were purchased from Sigma Chemical Company (St. Louis, MO). Other reagents were of analytical grade.

div.head: Isolation of mononuclear cells and cell viability
div.p: Human blood samples were obtained from ten healthy volunteers (male and female donors, 20--40 years) by venipuncture after informed consent had been obtained. Mononuclear cells were isolated by FycolI-Hypaque gradient separation [ 16]. Viability was determined by total cell eotmting and by determination of the cell fraction excluding trypan blue. Mononuclear cells consisted of about 90% lymphocytes, 9% monocytes and 0-2% polymorphonuclear leukocytes.

div.head: Irradiation conditions
div.p: TI-~ UVB spectral irradiance was measured with an IL 1700 Research Radiometer with a UVB-calibrated photodetector (SED 240) and filters (International Light, Newburyport, MA, USA). The emission spectrum of the lamp used in these experiments (UVM-57 Chromato-Vue lamp, UVP, San Gabriel, CA, USA), with a major peak emission at 303 rim, is shown in Fig. 1; 64.5% of the total emission was in the UVB range (280-315 nm), 33.3% in the UVA range (315--400 nm) and 2.2% in the UVC range (250-280 nm).

Mononuclear cells displayed in muitiwell dishes (5 × 105 cells ml-t ) in DPBS plus 1 g I -~ D-glucose were exposed to a UVB radiation source. A fluence rate of 0.30 W m-z at the cell suspension surface (63 cm from the light source) for 15 min was used (exposure dose, 270 J m-2). The height of the cell suspension in the multiwell dish was 0.4 cm in order to achieve adequate UVB penetration. Cells (irradiated and non-irradiated) were incubated at 37 0(2 in the dark for a 0-6 h period before assaying the enzyme activities.

div.head: Enzyme assays
div.p: Mononuclear cells were suspended in 130 mM KCi plus 30 mM phosphate buffer (pH 7.2) ( 1 × 106 cells ml-~) and lysed by sonication (10 s twice) using a Branson Sonifier model 450 (Branson Ultrasonics, Danbury, CT). Lysates were centrifuged at 20 000g for 10 min (4 °C). The supernatant was taken for enzyme and protein determinations.

Superoxide dismutase activity was assayed at 550 nm by monitoring the reduction rate of ferricytoehrome c in a reaction medium consisting of 50 mM phosphate buffer (pH 7.8), 100 p.M ethylenediaminetetraacetie acid (EDTA), 10 IzM cytochrome c, 50 p.M xanthine and 5 nM xanthine oxidase. One unit of superoxide dismutase activity was defined as the amount of enzyme that inhibited ferricytochrome c reduction by 50% under the assay conditions and corresponds to 11.0 pmol of CuZn-superoxide dismutase [ 17 ]. Total superoxide dismutase activity consisted of Mn-superoxide dismutase activity ( measured in the presence of I mM KCN) and CuZnsuperoxide dismutase activity.

Catalase activity was assayed by following the rate of HzOz consumption at 240 nm in a reaction medium containing 10 mM H202 and 50 mM phosphate buffer (pH 7.0). One unit of catalase corresponds to 1 i~mol of H202 consumed per minute per milligram of protein (initial rate) [ 18] and is equivalent to 0.28 pmol of pure catalase.

Superoxide dismutase and catalase show non-michaelian kinetics in which the enzyme activity is first order and linearly related to the substrate concentration. It is appropriate to express the activity in terms of the pure enzyme to enable comparison between the enzyme activities in various biological sources [6].

Glutathione peroxidase, as other peroxidases, behaves as a michaelian enzyme in the presence of excess hydrogen donor (5 mM GSH). In the conditions of the assay, I mU ( 1 nmol NADPH min-~) is equivalent to 0.16 pmol of pure Se glutathione peroxidase [ 19]. The activity of the Se-containing enzyme was determined as the activity with H,O2 as oxidant and the activity of the non-Se-containing enzyme was estimated as the difference between the activities measured with tert-butyl hydroperoxide and HzO2 as oxidants.

DT-diaphorase activity was measured with 0.5 mM NADH or NADPH as electron donor and 40 I~M 2,6-dichlorophenolindophenol (DCPIP) as electron acceptor. The rate of reduction of the dye was followed at 600 nm. The activity was expressed as the number of micromoles of DCPIP reduced per minute per milligram of protein [ 20].

Succinate dehydrogenase activity was determined by following the reduction of 60 IzM DCPIP coupled with phenazine methosulphate at 600 nm. The enzymatic activity was calculated from double reciprocal plots at infinite phenazine methosulphate concentration and expressed as the number of micromoles of DCPIP reduced per minute per milligram of protein [21].

Cytochrome oxidase was assayed spectrophotometrically at 550 nm by following the rate of oxidation of 50 I~M ferrocytoehrome c [22]. The activity was expressed as the pseudo-first-order reaction constant (k') per milligram of protein.
All enzyme activities were determined at 25 + 1 °(2 in a total reaction volume of 1.5 ml.
The protein content was determined with Folin--Ciocalteat]'s phenol reagent using bovine serum albumin as standard [23]; 1 mg of protein content corresponds to 0.7 × 106 cells.

div.head: Statistical analysis
div.p: The ANOVA test was applied for statistical analysis, and Duncan's test was performed as a multiple comparison procedure. The values are expressed in the tables and figures as the mean+ standard error of the mean (X+SEM) and are the average of five independent experiments.

div.head: Survival of mononuclear cells after UVB light exposure
div.p: Mononuclear cells were exposed to UVB radiation (280-315 nm) at a fluenee of 0.30 W m -2 for 15 min, and incubated in the dark for a 0--6 h period prior to assay. A slight decrease in viability was observed throughout the experiment, without biological significance; for 0, 3 and 6 h incubation, the viabilities were 0.98 + 0.01, 0.95 +0.02 and 0.93 _+0.01 respectively. Non-irradiated mononuclear cells showed no decrease in viability over the 6 h period. The number of cells in both light-exposed and non-irradiated samples remained constant throughout the experiment.

div.head: Effect of UVB irradiation on antioxidant enzyme activities
div.p: lase. CuZn-superoxide dismutase increased in activity by 1.3 and 1.8 times at 3 and 6 h after irradiation, and Mn-superoxide dismutase increased in activity by 1.3 times the base value at 3 h after irradiation and remained constant up to 6 h ( Fig. 2(B) ). Giutathione peroxidases also showed biphasic responses, although slightly different from the previously described profiles. Selenium-and non-selenium-containing glutathione peroxidases did not show significant changes in activity in the first phase (up to 3 h after irradiation), but showed increases of 1.3 and 1.8 times respectively at 6 h after irradiation (Fig. 2(C)).

Catalase showed a biphasic response to UVB irradiation with an important increase in activity: 1.5 and 3 times the base value were observed at 3 and 6 h after irradiation respectively ( Fig. 2(A) ). Copper-zinc and manganese superoxide dismutase showed a similar response profile to that of cata-

div.head: Effect of UVB irradiation on DT-diaphorase, cytochrome oxidase and succinate dehydrogenase activities
div.p: The activity of DT-diaphorase also showed a biphasic response to UVB irradiation with a maximal level of three times the base value. In the first phase after 3 h of incubation, increased activity was observed, and in the second phase, between 3 and 6 h post-UVB, a decreased activity was seen (Fig. 2(D)).

The membrane-bound mitochondrial enzymes succinate dehydrogenase and eytochrome oxidase did not change significantly in the first phase (up to 3 h), but markedly decreased (about 50% and 25% respectively) after 6 h of incubation in the dark (Fig. 3).

div.head: Effect of UVB irradiation on the antioxidant enzyme activities of cycloheximide-treated cells
div.p: Mononuclear cells were supplemented with 0.1 p,g ml -i cycloheximide in the incubation medium and irradiated. After a 3 h incubation period in the dark, the cells were assayed for antioxidant enzyme activity. The previously described increases in enzyme activity were eliminated by the protein synthesis inhibitor cycloheximide (Table 1 ). Table 1 Antioxidant enzyme and DT-diaphorase activities of human mononuclear cells after UVB irradiation in the presence of cycloheximide" ~Mononuclear cell suspensions were supplemented with 0.1 p,g ml-~ cycioheximide, exposed to a light fluence of 0.30 W m-2 for 15 min and incubated in the dark for 3 h. Supcroxide dismutase, catalase and DT-diaphorase activities were determined. The same protocol was used but with incubation in the dark for 4.5 h for the determination of glutathione peroxidase activity. Results are presented as means ( _+ SEM). bSignificant difference (P < 0.01 ) from control value. CNo difference from cona'ol value. dSignificant difference (P<0.01) from light-exposed cells and no diffewnce from control value.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: The adaptive phenomenon observed in human mononuclear cells after irradiation involves an increase in the activities of antioxidant enzymes (superoxide dismutase, catalase, glutathione peroxidase and DT-diaphorase), whereas cytochrome oxidase and succinate dehydrogenase do not show an increase in activity. This adaptive response, in terms of enzyme photoactivation and photodeactivation, is similar to that of the same cells exposed to visible light, when antioxidant enzymes were induced and the mitochondrial membrane-bound enzymes showed no increase [4]. When mononuclear cells were treated with RB and visible light, only catalase and superoxide dismutase showed increased activities [5].

Similar studies were carried out by irradiating skin or keratinocytes with UVB. When doses higher than 104 J m -2 were used, impairment of antioxidant enzymes was observed [24][25][26][27]; a slight induction of antioxidant enzymes was achieved at doses lower than 5 X 103 J m -2 [28,29].

It has been shown elsewhere that DT-diaphorase is induced by a large number of xenobiotics, and this induction has been shown to involve a net increase in newly synthesized enzyme [30]. The induction reported by us agrees with the view that both superoxide dismutase and DT-diaphorase may display a concerted antioxidant role in vivo [31]. DT-diaphorase catalyses the two-electron reduction of quinones and related quinonoid acceptors to quinols [ 32], whose auto-oxidation products, superoxide anion and hydrogen peroxide, must be kept at low intracellular steady state concentrations [ 6,33 ]. It is worth noting that, after reaching the maximum activity (3 h), DT-diaphorase behaves as cytochrome oxidase and succinate dehydrogenase, which start an inactivation phase.

The understanding of the regulation of these responses in eukaryotes is less complete than in bacteria, but this regulation almost certainly involves multiple mechanisms as antioxidant enzymes are coded by different genes. Since the induction of oxidative stress is highly controlled and a rapid elimination of reactive oxygen species is ensured by the action of antioxidant enzymes, reactive oxygen species seem to be particularly suitable as secondary messenger molecules

The light source was mainly restricted to 280-315 nm, which limits the number of absorbing species and enables the photoactive systems to be identified more easily. The process of signal transduction leading to the antioxidant adaptive response is certainly complex and probably includes endogenous photosensitization in which the generation of the excited species (A*) constitutes the first step, as follows A~A* A* +02"*02 +A + A* J¢~ O2 "~ 102q-A Molecules (A) absorbing in the UVB range include flavoproteins, quinones, cytochrome c (W band) and NAD (P)H, which may lead to the production of superoxide anion (type I process) or singlet oxygen (type II process) [35,36], both reactive oxygen species capable of acting as secondary messengers. This mcchanism provides a basis for explaining the effects of visible light, RB, RB and visible light and UVB (280-315 nm) light. RB is taken to its excited state (RB*) by energy transfer from endogenously generated excited carbonyls [ 37] RB + RCO* -o RB* + RCO Although different mechanisms are involved, the effect of UVB in human cells, producing both the inactivation of enzymes (succinate dehydrogcnase and cytochrome oxidase) and increases in enzyme activity (DT-diaphorase, superoxide dismutase and catalase) [4,5], may resemble the effect of UVC in prokaryotes in which irradiation produces structural damage, e.g. thymidine dimers, and triggers UV damage repair mechanisms [ 38].

In the present work, the expression of antioxidant enzymes after exposure to UVB reached a maximum level at 3--4 h after exposure. The treatment used was not cytotoxic, and allowed cells to develop an antioxidant adaptive response. The results presented in this work are in agreement with the concept that an inducible protective mechanism directed against photo-oxidative stress may exist in human cells. UVB radiation is known to penetrate almost completely the stratum corneum of Caucasian skin, and to irradiate a significant number of ceils in the peripheral circulation; 35% of 313 nm radiation may reach the viable layer of the skin [39]. The doses used in our study (0.3 W m -2) are comparable with those recorded for UVB solar irradiation at the Earth's surface [40,41 ]. Further studies on signal transduction leading to the antioxidant response triggered by photosensitization in human cells arc required, taking into account the possible role of reactive oxygen species as secondary messengers.
